---
title: 'Quality and Legitimacy in ECEC Mapping: How Can Mapping Contribute to the
  Protection of Children and Their Families?'
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---

<div id="csl-bib-meta-UDWF2RVD" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-UDWF2RVD" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Midtskogen's book explores the role of family in child welfare services from various professional viewpoints. They examine how families interact with child welfare workers, the guidelines that shape these interactions, and the impact of societal beliefs on child welfare practices. The book aims to help child welfare workers understand the crucial role families play in children's lives. It is a valuable resource for those working in child welfare, policymakers, researchers, and educators. Although the book focuses on Norwegian child welfare, its insights are applicable globally. This comprehensive guide is designed to improve the support provided to children and their families, ensuring their protection and well-being.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-UDWF2RVD" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Child Welfare, Family Significance, Professional CW Work, Social Structures, Ideologies, Norwegian CW Work
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-UDWF2RVD" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    This book focuses on the significance of family in child welfare (CW) services from multidisciplinary perspectives. The authors are concerned with how families experience encounters with CW workers, how professional CW work with families is guided by rules and principles, and how social structures and ideologies influence CW work. Taken together, the chapters contribute to a comprehensive understanding of how CW workers should understand the importance of family for children.The book is important for everyone who works with the welfare of children and their families, and for those who educate CW workers. Although the context for many of the discussions in the book is Norwegian CW work, the topics are general, recognisable and relevant to similar discussions in other countries. The book is intended for CW workers, policymakers, researchers, and teachers and students in social work and child welfare study programmes.
  </article>
